docs.title: SWB API Client
docs.text: A powerful Python CLI client for querying the Südwestdeutscher Bibliotheksverbund (SWB) library catalog via the SRU (Search/Retrieve via URL) API.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The SWB API Client provides both an interactive terminal UI and a comprehensive command-line interface for searching German library catalogs. Whether you're a researcher, librarian, or developer, this tool makes it easy to discover and access bibliographic information.

docs.title: 🖥️ Interactive Terminal UI
docs.text:
• User-friendly terminal interface powered by Textual
  • Real-time search with formatted results
  • Keyboard shortcuts for efficient navigation
  • Perfect for exploring without memorizing commands

docs.title: 🔍 Powerful Search Capabilities
docs.text:
• Simple keyword search or advanced CQL queries
  • Multiple search indices (title, author, ISBN, ISSN, subject, etc.)
  • Sort by relevance, year, author, or title
  • Index scanning for auto-completion
  • Band/linking search for multi-volume works

docs.title: 📚 Multi-Catalog Support
docs.text:
• 6 pre-configured library profiles: SWB, K10plus, DNB, GBV, BVB, HeBIS
  • Switch between catalogs with a single option
  • Custom endpoint support

docs.title: 📖 Library Holdings
docs.text:
• See which libraries have items
  • Access information (online, VPN, campus-only)
  • Collection and location details

docs.title: 🎯 Developer-Friendly
docs.text:
• Clean Python API for integration
  • Multiple output formats (MARCXML, MODS, TurboMARC, etc.)
  • Type-safe with full mypy support
  • Well-tested (77 tests, 63% coverage)

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Install
uv pip install -e .

# Launch interactive UI
swb-tui

# Or use CLI
swb search "Python programming"
swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0 --holdings
swb search "Goethe" --profile dnb

docs.title: explain()
docs.text:
Retrieve server capabilities and configuration (SRU explain operation).

The explain operation returns information about the server including: - Server and database information - Available search indices - Supported record schemas/formats - Configuration details

Returns:

Type Description ExplainResponse

ExplainResponse containing server capabilities.

Raises:

Type Description RequestException

If the API request fails.

ValueError

If the response cannot be parsed.

Example

client = SWBClient() info = client.explain() print(f"Database: {info.database_info.title}") print(f"Available indices: {len(info.indices)}") for schema in info.schemas: ... print(f" - {schema.name}")

docs.title: scan(scan_clause, response_position=1, maximum_terms=20)
docs.text:
Scan an index for terms (for auto-completion and browsing).

The scan operation allows browsing index terms, which is useful for: - Auto-completion in search interfaces - Exploring available terms before searching - Finding correct spellings

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default scan_clause str

CQL scan clause (e.g., "pica.per=Goe" to find authors starting with "Goe").

required response_position int

Position in the term list to start from (1-based).

1 maximum_terms int

Maximum number of terms to return.

20

Returns:

Type Description ScanResponse

ScanResponse containing the list of terms.

Raises:

Type Description RequestException

If the API request fails.

ValueError

If the response cannot be parsed.

Example

client = SWBClient() response = client.scan("pica.per=Goe", maximum_terms=10) for term in response.terms: ... print(f"{term.value}: {term.number_of_records} records")

docs.title: search(query, record_format=RecordFormat.MARCXML, start_record=1, maximum_records=10, index=None, sort_by=None, sort_order=SortOrder.DESCENDING, record_packing='xml')
docs.text:
Search the SWB catalog using CQL query syntax.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default query str

Search query. Can be a simple keyword or full CQL query.

required record_format RecordFormat

Desired format for the results.

MARCXML start_record int

Position of first record to return (1-based).

1 maximum_records int

Maximum number of records to return.

10 index SearchIndex | None

Search index to use. If provided, query is treated as a simple keyword search in that index.

None sort_by SortBy | None

Sort results by relevance, year, author, or title.

None sort_order SortOrder

Sort order (ascending or descending). Default is descending.

DESCENDING record_packing str

How records are packed in the response. Valid values: "xml" (default) - Records embedded as XML "string" - Records escaped as strings

'xml'

Returns:

Type Description SearchResponse

SearchResponse containing the search results.

Raises:

Type Description RequestException

If the API request fails.

ValueError

If the response cannot be parsed or recordPacking is invalid.

Example

client = SWBClient() results = client.search( ... "Python", ... index=SearchIndex.TITLE, ... sort_by=SortBy.YEAR, ... sort_order=SortOrder.DESCENDING ... ) print(f"Found {results.total_results} results")

docs.text:
Search for records related to a specific publication (band/linking search).

This method is useful for finding related publications in multi-volume works, series, or hierarchical bibliographic relationships. It uses K10plus-specific search attributes to retrieve linked records.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default ppn str

PPN (PICA Production Number) of the parent record to find related records for.

required relation_type RelationType

Type of relationship to search for (e.g., parent, child, family, related, thesaurus).

required record_type RecordType

Type of records to retrieve (bibliographic or authority). Default is bibliographic records.

BIBLIOGRAPHIC record_format RecordFormat

Desired format for the results.

MARCXML start_record int

Position of first record to return (1-based).

1 maximum_records int

Maximum number of records to return.

10 sort_by SortBy | None

Sort results by relevance, year, author, or title.

None sort_order SortOrder

Sort order (ascending or descending). Default is descending.

DESCENDING record_packing str

How records are packed ("xml" or "string"). Default is "xml".

'xml'

Returns:

Type Description SearchResponse

SearchResponse containing the related records.

Raises:

Type Description RequestException

If the API request fails.

ValueError

If the response cannot be parsed.

Example

docs.title: API Overview
docs.text: The SWB API Client provides a clean Python API for integrating library catalog searches into your applications.

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
from swb import SWBClient, SearchIndex

# Create client
with SWBClient() as client:
    # Simple search
    response = client.search(
        "Python programming",
        index=SearchIndex.TITLE,
        maximum_records=10
    )

    # Process results
    for result in response.results:
        print(f"{result.title} by {result.author} ({result.year})")

docs.title: SWBClient
docs.text:
The main client class for making API requests.

from swb import SWBClient

# Default SWB endpoint
client = SWBClient()

# Custom endpoint
client = SWBClient(base_url="https://custom.sru.endpoint.de/sru")

# With timeout
client = SWBClient(timeout=60)

docs.title: ISBN Lookup
docs.text:
with SWBClient() as client:
    response = client.search_by_isbn("978-3-16-148410-0")

    if response.results:
        book = response.results[0]
        print(f"Found: {book.title}")

        # Check holdings
        for holding in book.holdings:
            print(f"Available at: {holding.library_name}")

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
from swb import SWBClient
import requests

with SWBClient() as client:
    try:
        response = client.search("query")
    except requests.HTTPError as e:
        if e.response.status_code == 403:
            print("Access denied - try different profile")
        else:
            print(f"HTTP error: {e}")
    except ValueError as e:
        print(f"Invalid query: {e}")
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Unexpected error: {e}")

docs.title: Type Safety
docs.text:
The API is fully typed and works with mypy:

from swb import SWBClient, SearchResponse, SearchResult

def process_results(response: SearchResponse) -> list[str]:
    """Extract titles from response."""
    return [
        result.title
        for result in response.results
        if result.title is not None
    ]

with SWBClient() as client:
    response: SearchResponse = client.search("Python")
    titles: list[str] = process_results(response)

docs.title: Docstrings
docs.text:
Use Google-style docstrings:

def search(self, query: str, maximum_records: int = 10) -> SearchResponse:
    """Search the catalog with a query.

    Args:
        query: Search query in CQL format
        maximum_records: Maximum number of records to return

    Returns:
        SearchResponse object containing results

    Raises:
        ValueError: If query is invalid
        HTTPError: If server returns an error
    """
    pass

def test_search_basic(client: SWBClient) -> None:
    """Test basic search functionality."""
    response = client.search("Python", maximum_records=5)
    assert response.total_results > 0
    assert len(response.results) <= 5

Example:

Adds support for MADS record format

## Why

- Added MADS to RecordFormat enum
- Updated parser to handle MADS XML
- Added tests for MADS parsing

## Testing

from swb import SWBClient

with SWBClient() as client:
    response = client.search("Python", maximum_records=100)

docs.title: Advanced Processing
docs.text:
from swb import SWBClient, SearchIndex, SortBy, SortOrder

def find_recent_books(query: str, min_year: int = 2020):
    """Find recent books on a topic."""
    with SWBClient() as client:
        response = client.search(
            query,
            index=SearchIndex.SUBJECT,
            sort_by=SortBy.YEAR,
            sort_order=SortOrder.DESCENDING,
            maximum_records=50
        )

        recent = [
            r for r in response.results
            if r.year and int(r.year) >= min_year
        ]

        return recent

# Use it
books = find_recent_books("Machine Learning", min_year=2022)
for book in books:
    print(f"{book.title} - {book.year}")

docs.title: Holdings Analysis
docs.text:
from swb import SWBClient
from collections import Counter

def analyze_holdings(isbn: str):
    """Analyze library holdings for a book."""
    with SWBClient() as client:
        response = client.search_by_isbn(isbn)

        if not response.results:
            return None

        book = response.results[0]
        libraries = [h.library_name for h in book.holdings]

        return {
            "title": book.title,
            "total_holdings": len(book.holdings),
            "libraries": Counter(libraries),
            "online_access": sum(1 for h in book.holdings if h.access_url)
        }

# Use it
stats = analyze_holdings("978-3-17-042177-6")
print(f"Available at {stats['total_holdings']} locations")
print(f"Online access: {stats['online_access']}")

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Start broad, refine: Begin with general terms, add filters
  2. Use appropriate indices: Author for names, Title for works
  3. Leverage profiles: K10plus for coverage, DNB for completeness
  4. Check holdings: Add --holdings for availability
  5. Export results: Save to files for further processing
  6. Handle errors: Use try-catch in scripts
  7. Respect servers: Don't hammer endpoints

docs.title: Command Line Interface
docs.text: Complete reference for all CLI commands and options.

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text:
Available for all commands:

swb [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]
Option Description --version Show version and exit --verbose, -v Enable verbose output (DEBUG level) --quiet, -q Quiet mode (errors only) --help Show help message

docs.title: search
docs.text:
Search the catalog with a query.

swb search [OPTIONS] QUERY

Options:

Option Short Default Description --index -i title Search index to use --format -f marcxml Record format --max -m 10 Maximum number of records --start-record 1 Starting record position --sort-by Sort results by field --sort-order descending Sort order --output -o Save results to file --raw Include raw XML in output --holdings Show library holdings --packing xml Record packing mode --profile -p swb Library catalog profile --url Custom SRU endpoint URL

Examples:

# Basic search
swb search "Python programming"

# Search with options
swb search "Goethe" --index author --max 20 --sort-by year

# Search with holdings
swb search "Machine Learning" --holdings --profile k10plus

# Save results
swb search "Python" --output results.txt --raw

docs.title: isbn
docs.text:
Search by ISBN number.

swb isbn [OPTIONS] ISBN

Options: Same as search command

Examples:

# Basic ISBN search
swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0

# With holdings
swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0 --holdings

# Different profile
swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0 --profile dnb

docs.title: issn
docs.text:
Search by ISSN number.

swb issn [OPTIONS] ISSN

Options: Same as search command

Examples:

swb issn 0028-0836
swb issn 0028-0836 --holdings --profile k10plus

docs.title: related
docs.text:
Search for related records (multi-volume works, series).

swb related [OPTIONS] PPN

Options:

Option Description --relation-type Type of relation (child, parent, family, related, thesaurus) --record-type Record type (bibliographic, authority) Plus all search options

Examples:

# Find volumes of a multi-volume work
swb related 267838395 --relation-type child

# Find parent record
swb related 123456789 --relation-type parent

# Find entire family
swb related 267838395 --relation-type family --max 50

docs.title: scan
docs.text:
Browse index terms for auto-completion.

swb scan [OPTIONS] SCAN_CLAUSE

Options:

Option Description --max Maximum terms to return --position Starting position in term list --profile Library catalog profile --url Custom SRU endpoint

Examples:

# Find authors starting with "Goe"
swb scan "pica.per=Goe"

# Find titles
swb scan "pica.tit=Python" --max 20

# Different profile
swb scan "pica.per=Goethe" --profile dnb

docs.title: explain
docs.text:
Get server capabilities and configuration.

swb explain [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --profile Library catalog profile --url Custom SRU endpoint

Examples:

# Default server
swb explain

# Different profiles
swb explain --profile k10plus
swb explain --profile dnb

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the basics of using the SWB API Client.

docs.title: Your First Search
docs.text:
The simplest way to start is with a basic search:

swb search "Python programming"

This will search for books about Python programming in the default SWB catalog and display formatted results with titles, authors, and publication years.

docs.title: Understanding the Output
docs.text:
A typical search result looks like this:

Record 1:
  Title: Python Programming: An Introduction to Computer Science
  Author: Zelle, John
  Year: 2016
  Publisher: Franklin, Beedle & Associates
  ISBN: 978-1-59028-241-0

docs.title: Search by Keyword
docs.text:
# Simple keyword search
swb search "Machine Learning"

# Search in specific index
swb search "Goethe" --index author

# Limit number of results
swb search "Python" --max 10

docs.title: Search by ISBN
docs.text: swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0

docs.title: Search by ISSN
docs.text: swb issn 0028-0836

docs.title: List Available Options
docs.text:
# Show available record formats
swb formats

# Show searchable indices
swb indices

# Show library catalog profiles
swb profiles

docs.title: Using Different Catalogs
docs.text:
The SWB client supports multiple German library catalogs:

# Search in K10plus catalog (covers more of Germany)
swb search "Python" --profile k10plus

# Search in German National Library
swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0 --profile dnb

# Search in Bavarian Library Network
swb search "Goethe" --profile bvb

Available profiles:

  • swb - Southwestern Germany (default)
  • k10plus - Northern and southwestern Germany
  • dnb - German National Library
  • gvk - Northern Germany
  • bvb - Bavaria
  • hebis - Hesse and parts of Rhineland-Palatinate

docs.title: Viewing Library Holdings
docs.text:
To see which libraries have a book and how to access it:

# Show holdings for an ISBN
swb isbn 978-3-17-025295-0 --holdings

# Show holdings in search results
swb search "Autismus" --holdings --max 3

The holdings display shows:

  • Library names and locations
  • Online access URLs
  • Access restrictions (VPN, campus-only, etc.)
  • Collections and call numbers

docs.title: Sorting Results
docs.text:
Sort search results by different criteria:

# Sort by year (newest first)
swb search "Python" --sort-by year

# Sort by year (oldest first)
swb search "Python" --sort-by year --sort-order ascending

# Sort by author
swb search "Machine Learning" --sort-by author

docs.title: Saving Results
docs.text:
Export search results to a file:

# Save formatted output
swb search "Python" --output results.txt

# Include raw XML data
swb search "Python" --output results.txt --raw

docs.title: Interactive Terminal UI
docs.text:
For a more user-friendly experience, try the interactive TUI:

swb-tui

The TUI provides:

  • Ctrl+S - Execute search
  • Ctrl+C - Clear results
  • Ctrl+Q - Quit application
  • Dropdown menus for all options
  • Scrollable results

See the TUI Guide for more details.

docs.title: No Results Found
docs.text:
If your search returns no results:

  1. Check spelling - Try wildcards: "Pytho*"
  2. Broaden search - Use fewer keywords
  3. Try different index - Switch from title to keyword search
  4. Check catalog - Some books may only be in specific catalogs

docs.title: Connection Timeouts
docs.text:
The client uses a 30-second timeout. For slow connections:

from swb import SWBClient

# Increase timeout to 60 seconds
client = SWBClient(timeout=60)

docs.title: Server Errors (403 Forbidden)
docs.text:
If you get access denied errors:

  • Try a different profile (--profile k10plus or --profile dnb)
  • Check if your IP is blocked
  • Some catalogs may require VPN access

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will help you install the SWB API Client on your system.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing, make sure you have:

  • Python 3.12 or higher installed
  • Internet connection for API access
  • uv (recommended) or pip package manager

docs.title: Installing uv
docs.text:
We recommend using uv for fast and reliable package management.

macOS/LinuxWindowsWith pip 
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"

pip install uv

docs.title: From Source (Recommended)
docs.text:
Clone the repository and install in development mode:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/jvanvinkenroye/swb.git
cd swb

# Create virtual environment
uv venv --seed

# Activate virtual environment
source .venv/bin/activate  # On macOS/Linux
# or
.venv\Scripts\activate     # On Windows

# Install the package
uv pip install -e .

Development Installation

The -e flag installs the package in editable mode, which means changes to the source code will be immediately available without reinstalling.

docs.title: With Development Dependencies
docs.text:
If you plan to contribute or run tests:

# Install with dev dependencies
uv pip install -e ".[dev]"

# Or sync all dependencies
uv sync --dev

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify that everything works:

# Check CLI version
swb --version

# Test a simple search
swb search "Python" --max 5

# Launch the TUI
swb-tui

You should see the version number and search results if everything is installed correctly.

docs.title: Bash
docs.text:
Add to ~/.bashrc:

eval "$(_SWB_COMPLETE=bash_source swb)"

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text:

eval "$(_SWB_COMPLETE=zsh_source swb)"

docs.title: Fish

Add to ~/.config/fish/completions/swb.fish:

eval (env _SWB_COMPLETE=fish_source swb)

docs.title: SSL Certificate Errors
docs.text:
If you encounter SSL certificate errors:

macOSUbuntu/DebianWindows 
brew install ca-certificates

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install ca-certificates

Update your certificates via Windows Update or download from certifi.io

docs.title: Permission Errors
docs.text:
If you get permission errors during installation:

# Don't use sudo with uv - use virtual environments instead
uv venv
source .venv/bin/activate
uv pip install -e .

docs.title: Python Version Issues
docs.text:
Make sure you're using Python 3.12 or higher:

python --version
# or
python3 --version

If you need to install Python 3.12:

macOSUbuntu/DebianWindows 
brew install python@3.12

sudo apt-get install python3.12

Download from python.org

docs.title: Updating
docs.text:
To update to the latest version:

cd swb
git pull
uv pip install -e .

docs.title: Uninstalling
docs.text:
To remove the SWB client:

uv pip uninstall swb

docs.title: Library Catalog Profiles
docs.text: The SWB client supports multiple German library union catalogs through pre-configured profiles, making it easy to search different catalogs without manually specifying endpoint URLs.

docs.title: SWB (Default)
docs.text:
swb search "query" --profile swb
  • Name: Südwestdeutscher Bibliotheksverbund
  • Region: Baden-Württemberg, Saarland, Saxony
  • URL: https://sru.k10plus.de/swb
  • Best for: Books in southwestern German libraries

docs.title: K10plus
docs.text:
swb search "query" --profile k10plus
  • Name: K10plus Verbundkatalog
  • Region: Northern and southwestern Germany
  • URL: https://sru.k10plus.de/opac-de-627
  • Best for: Widest coverage including many NRW libraries

docs.title: DNB
docs.text:
swb search "query" --profile dnb
  • Name: Deutsche Nationalbibliothek
  • Region: National (all of Germany)
  • URL: https://services.dnb.de/sru/dnb
  • Best for: Comprehensive national bibliography

docs.title: GBV
docs.text:
swb search "query" --profile gvk
  • Name: Gemeinsamer Verbundkatalog (GBV)
  • Region: Northern Germany
  • URL: https://sru.gbv.de/gvk
  • Best for: Northern German libraries

docs.title: BVB
docs.text:
swb search "query" --profile bvb
  • Name: Bibliotheksverbund Bayern
  • Region: Bavaria
  • URL: https://sru.bib-bvb.de/bvb
  • Best for: Bavarian libraries

docs.title: HeBIS
docs.text:
swb search "query" --profile hebis
  • Name: Hessisches BibliotheksInformationsSystem
  • Region: Hesse and parts of Rhineland-Palatinate
  • URL: https://sru.hebis.de/sru
  • Best for: Libraries in Hesse

docs.title: With Search
docs.text:
# Search K10plus
swb search "Python programming" --profile k10plus

# Search DNB
swb search "Goethe" --profile dnb --max 20

docs.title: With ISBN/ISSN
docs.text:
# Check holdings in K10plus
swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0 --profile k10plus --holdings

# Search ISSN in DNB
swb issn 0028-0836 --profile dnb

docs.title: With Related Records
docs.text:
# Find related records in different catalog
swb related 267838395 --relation-type child --profile k10plus

docs.title: With Scan
docs.text:
# Scan authors in DNB
swb scan "pica.per=Goethe" --profile dnb

docs.title: With Explain
docs.text:
# Get server capabilities for different profiles
swb explain --profile k10plus
swb explain --profile dnb

docs.title: Profile Priority
docs.text:
When multiple options are specified, they are applied in this order:

  1. Custom URL (highest priority)
  2. Profile option
  3. Default profile (swb)

Example:

# Custom URL overrides profile
swb search "query" --profile k10plus --url https://custom.endpoint.de/sru
# Uses: custom.endpoint.de

# Profile overrides default
swb search "query" --profile dnb
# Uses: services.dnb.de

# Default when nothing specified
swb search "query"
# Uses: sru.k10plus.de/swb

docs.title: Which Profile to Use?
docs.text:
For general searches: Use k10plus - it has the widest coverage

By region:

  • Baden-Württemberg, Saarland: swb
  • Bavaria: bvb
  • Hesse: hebis
  • Northern Germany: gvk or k10plus
  • National coverage: dnb
  • NRW libraries: k10plus (includes many NRW holdings)

By library type:

  • University libraries: k10plus or regional profile
  • National bibliography: dnb
  • Public libraries: Regional profile (swb, bvb, hebis)

docs.title: Custom Endpoints
docs.text:
If you need to access a catalog not in the profiles:

swb search "query" --url https://your-sru-endpoint.de/sru

This bypasses profile selection and connects directly to your custom URL.

docs.title: Comparing Catalogs
docs.text:
Search the same query across multiple catalogs:

# Search in SWB
swb isbn 978-3-17-042177-6 --profile swb --holdings

# Same search in K10plus
swb isbn 978-3-17-042177-6 --profile k10plus --holdings

# Same search in DNB
swb isbn 978-3-17-042177-6 --profile dnb

This helps find the most complete holdings information.

docs.title: Profile Configuration
docs.text:
Profiles are defined in src/swb/profiles.py:

@dataclass
class CatalogProfile:
    name: str
    url: str
    display_name: str
    description: str
    region: str

docs.title: Adding Custom Profiles
docs.text:
To add a custom profile programmatically:

from swb.profiles import PROFILES, CatalogProfile

# Add custom profile
PROFILES["custom"] = CatalogProfile(
    name="custom",
    url="https://custom.sru.endpoint.de/sru",
    display_name="Custom Library Network",
    description="My custom library network",
    region="Custom Region"
)

# Use it
from swb import SWBClient
client = SWBClient(base_url=PROFILES["custom"].url)

docs.title: Profile Limitations
docs.text:
Important Notes

  • Not all profiles support all features
  • Some catalogs may have access restrictions
  • Holdings information varies by catalog
  • Response times differ between servers
  • Some profiles may require VPN access

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
403 Forbidden Error: - Try a different profile (k10plus or dnb) - Check if catalog requires authentication - Some catalogs may block certain IPs

No Results: - Not all content is in all catalogs - Try broader search terms - Use DNB for comprehensive national coverage

Slow Responses: - Some servers are slower than others - Consider using k10plus for best performance - Adjust timeout in code if needed

docs.title: Terminal User Interface (TUI)
docs.text: The SWB client includes an experimental interactive terminal UI powered by Textual, providing a user-friendly way to explore library catalogs without memorizing CLI commands.

docs.title: Launching the TUI
docs.text:
Start the interactive interface:

swb-tui

The TUI will open in your terminal with a clean, organized interface.

docs.title: Interface Overview
docs.text: The TUI consists of several sections:

docs.title: Search Form
docs.text:
At the top, you'll find the search form with:

  • Query Input - Enter your search terms
  • Search Index - Dropdown to select where to search (title, author, ISBN, etc.)
  • Record Format - Choose output format (MARCXML, MODS, etc.)
  • Max Records - Limit number of results
  • Search Button - Execute the search

docs.title: Results Display
docs.text:
Below the form, search results appear in a scrollable container showing:

  • Record number
  • Title
  • Author
  • Publication year
  • Publisher
  • ISBN (when available)

docs.title: Status Messages
docs.text:
• Loading indicators during searches
  • Error messages with helpful suggestions
  • Result counts and status updates

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text:
The TUI is designed for keyboard-driven workflows:

Shortcut Action Ctrl+S Execute search Ctrl+C Clear results Ctrl+Q Quit application Tab Move to next field Shift+Tab Move to previous field ↑ ↓ Navigate dropdowns/results Enter Confirm selection Esc Close dropdown

Efficient Navigation

Use Tab to quickly move between fields and Ctrl+S to search without reaching for the mouse.

docs.title: Basic Search
docs.text:
1. Enter search terms in the Query field
  2. (Optional) Select search index from dropdown
  3. Press Ctrl+S or click Search button
  4. Scroll through results

docs.title: Refining Searches
docs.text:
1. Clear previous results with Ctrl+C
  2. Modify search parameters
  3. Execute new search with Ctrl+S

docs.title: Search Indices
docs.text:
Available in the Search Index dropdown:

  • Title (default) - Search book/article titles
  • Author - Search by author name
  • Subject - Search by subject headings
  • ISBN - Search by ISBN number
  • ISSN - Search by ISSN number
  • Keyword - Full-text keyword search
  • All Fields - Search across all metadata
  • Publisher - Search by publisher name
  • Year - Search by publication year

docs.title: Record Formats
docs.text:
Available output formats:

  • MARCXML (default) - Standard bibliographic format
  • TurboMARC - Optimized MARC XML
  • MODS - Metadata Object Description Schema
  • PICA XML - PICA format
  • Dublin Core - Simple metadata format

docs.title: Real-Time Search
docs.text: Results appear immediately after the search completes, with a loading indicator during processing.

docs.title: Formatted Output
docs.text:
Results are displayed in an easy-to-read format with:

  • Clear field labels
  • Proper spacing
  • Consistent formatting
  • Scrollable container for many results

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
The TUI provides helpful error messages:

  • Connection errors with suggestions
  • No results found notifications
  • Invalid query syntax warnings
  • Server error explanations

docs.title: CQL Queries
docs.text:
Enter complex queries directly in the Query field:

pica.tit="Python" and pica.per="Guido"

pica.tit="Machine Learning" and pica.ejr=2023

docs.title: Wildcard Searches
docs.text:
Use wildcards in your queries:

Pytho*

*learning*

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
Current Limitations

The experimental TUI currently has some limitations:

  • No library holdings display (use CLI for holdings)
  • No profile switching (uses default SWB catalog)
  • No result export functionality
  • Limited to 100 records per search

These features may be added in future versions.

docs.title: Fast Searching
docs.text:
1. Use keyboard shortcuts exclusively
  2. Keep common searches in clipboard
  3. Use wildcards liberally
  4. Start with broad terms, refine as needed

docs.title: Efficient Navigation
docs.text:
• Tab through all fields quickly
  • Use arrow keys in dropdowns instead of mouse
  • Ctrl+C to reset and start fresh search
  • Ctrl+Q for quick exit

docs.title: Working with Results
docs.text:
• Scroll through results with arrow keys or mouse wheel
  • Copy text directly from the terminal
  • Take note of ISBNs for CLI commands with holdings

docs.title: TUI Won't Start
docs.text:
If the TUI fails to launch:

# Check if textual is installed
python -c "import textual; print(textual.__version__)"

# Reinstall if missing
uv pip install textual>=6.12.0

docs.title: Display Issues
docs.text:
If the TUI looks broken:

  • Resize your terminal window (minimum 80x24)
  • Try a different terminal emulator
  • Check terminal color support

docs.title: Slow Performance
docs.text:
If searches are slow:

  • Reduce max records setting
  • Use more specific search terms
  • Check network connection
  • Try different search index

docs.title: Switching to CLI
docs.text:
For advanced features not available in TUI, use the CLI:

# Holdings information
swb isbn 978-3-16-148410-0 --holdings

# Different catalog profiles
swb search "Python" --profile k10plus

# Export results
swb search "Python" --output results.txt

# Sorting
swb search "Python" --sort-by year
